Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: SaaS-Based Procurement and CRM Systems for Local Food Markets
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project will develop a new methodology for data interchange in the agricultural industry. GreenLeaf Market is developing application program interfaces to enable the automated transfer of data to enterprise resource planning systems through a representational state transfer interface interchangeable with a webservice. This platform automatically identifies and aggregates agricultural market information while enabling this information to be integrated into the purchaser's business systems.

If successfully commercialized, the application stands to significantly reduce post-harvest spoilage costs, now in the tens of billions of dollars for the United States. It will increase productivity for purchasers, assist the producer in identifying emerging markets, reduce the distance agricultural products must travel, boost the local economy, improve the food security of the US, and lower the overall cost of food by reducing the gap between supply and demand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two million small and mid-sized US farms struggle to take advantage of the increase in demand for local foods. A disaggregate, manual local food system results in an information gap bewtween supply and demand. Over 40% of post-harvest product is lost due to spoilage. This inefficient market is one reason why 337 small to mid-sized farms (revenues $1,000-1,000,000) go out of business every week acording to the USDA Census.

This SBIR Phase II project developed a Software as a Service (SaaS) based platform methodology for data interchange in the agricultural industry. The application program interfaces to enable the automated transfer of data to enterprise resource planning systems through a representational state transfer interface interchangeable with a webservice. This platform automatically identifies and aggregates agricultural market information while enabling this information to be integrated into the purchaser's business systems. 

The seller and product data has been made available to the public via a free mobile application, Locavore, on iOS and Android operating systems. Information is geocoded and mapped based of user's GPS location.

This platform significantly reduces post-harvest spoilage costs, increases productivity for purchasers, assists producers in identifying emerging markets, reduces the distance agricultural products must travel, boosts the local economy, and improves the food security of the US.
